comments.commentBody: Yes, that tends to be true for families with both parents working full-time. When you have a child who goes to sleep at 8pm and don't get home until 6pm or 7pm, it's hard logistically. I have been there myself. I don't think Europeans typically keep better work hours. (Not to mention, most "professional" Americans still have do additional work at home.)

I also grew up with family dinners. We all ate together. I was surprised to learn that today, many kids do not eat with their parents or even their siblings. Some eat alone, in their rooms, in front of the TV or their computer. I can't imagine how these kids will learn eating habits and dining skills - which you need in the business world.

Well, your salient point is how cultural norms have totally changed (in my lifetime, and I'm in my mid-50s) and that we can't dump blame on people without looking at the whole cultural environment.

When I was a kid, almost every mom was a SAHM -- she stayed home, cooked meals and was there when you got home from school. We sat down every night to a simple home cooked meal, fresh ingredients, salads, whole milk, fresh veggies.

I also walked home from school in K-6, and my mom was there to serve me a bowl of homemade soup, and a home made sandwich (peanut butter, tuna, chicken, etc.).

Few kids get this today. Most moms work outside the home! Many kids grow up in day care, before-school care, after-school care. There is nobody to cook! They are stuffed with snacks and prepared food items.

American families cannot realistically survive on one income -- not in this high priced world of expensive homes, and six digit college educations. Many are unemployed or underemployed -- they do not have to power to say "no" to long hours, unpaid overtime, "face time", travel for work and so forth. Work even follows us home, on computers or cell phones.

Kids are pressured (in the interest of the "right college") to do umpteen afterschool activities -- band, soccer, football, cheerleading, etc. -- and parents have to drive them to all this.

None of this computes to "any time whatsoever for a family to sit down together to a meal", not even once a week.

I have been told, and I wonder if it is true, that in "typical" American families, children eat earlier and apart from the parents.  Since I never did that, I cannot say.  But if it is common, that may explain why "typical" American children do not learn good habits of eating and good behavior while eating--in other words, that eating together at family meals is a social and cultural experience.

The NRA and its rabid followers do not seem to have the ability to look to the future.
In the past we have seen the irresponsible use of firearms by people who never should have been allowed to have them. That has contributed to more restrictive gun laws. Not too many years ago, you could carry a gun on the street in California and a concealed weapon permits were given for reasonable reasons.

Then a spate of gun violence and the demonstration by the Black Muslims bringing guns into the capitol building precipitated a series of stricter gun laws. The NRA found itself under attack and has responded with a constant campaign to convince people that they need guns for self defense.

There is a core of followers who have been convinced that the government is coming to get them for some nefarious reason, and they must be able to defend themselves from this perceived government tyranny. The hunters and target shooters have fallen for this propaganda also, and between them and the paranoid right wing, them the money is there to lobby for even less restrictive gun laws.

What these people do not see, is that this is going to came back at them eventually. All it will take is another few episodes of killing by some deranged gun owner and the public will demand even stricter gun laws. The NRA does not seem to recognize that there are deranged people that want guns to kill people. If you oppose reasonable laws, eventually you will get unreasonable ones.

Such considerations about women's status if they are full time moms are limited to at least those parents with a middle class or above income.  For the rest of us, working is not something we "choose" to insure our full idenity as equal to our husbands and men in general.  We work because we need the money. As a working mom I needed the stay at home moms because they often were my  kids before and after school babysitters and they were the ones who helped make my neighborhood a community because they knew all the people who lived in it.  I was too busy working to form such relationships. I now have a daughter who is a stay at home mom with three children. She does nurse on demand and certainly works very hard to nurture her kids.  I also have a daughter-in-law who has a full time career and only took three months off for each of her two children. She would never consider being a full time mom because she wouldn't be very good at it.  She loves the career she has chosen and has no guilt about it. However, for most of the moms who work, and they are the majority, I doubt that much time is spent worrying about their status.  They are too busy just trying to make house payments and finding ways to pay for their children's braces and school supplies.
